### pycaret version checks

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported [here](https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret/issues).

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret/releases) of pycaret.

- [ ] I have confirmed this bug exists on the develop branch of pycaret (pip install -U git+https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret.git@develop).


### Issue Description

Whenever I try any values larger than 1 for the start of the forecast horizon I can't train any models with exogenous variables.

### Reproducible Example

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from pycaret.time_series import TSForecastingExperiment

dates = pd.date_range('2019-01-1', '2022-04-15')

df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randint(0, 4000, size=len(dates)), index=dates, columns=['qtde'])

df = df.assign(exoge_1=lambda x: x.qtde*np.random.randint(0, 10))

exp = TSForecastingExperiment()

exp.setup(
    data=df,
    fh=np.arange(1, 4),
    session_id=5005,
    seasonal_period=['Y'],
    fold=5,
    enforce_exogenous=True,
    target='qtde',
)
#this works
best = exp.compare_models(errors='raise', include=['knn_cds_dt'])

exp.setup(
    data=df,
    fh=np.arange(2, 4),
    session_id=5005,
    seasonal_period=['Y'],
    fold=5,
    enforce_exogenous=True,
    target='qtde',
)

exp.plot_model(
    plot='cv',
)
#this dosen't
best = exp.compare_models(errors='raise', include=['knn_cds_dt'])
```


### Expected Behavior

Models to be trained with no problems

body:
Here is the code to just reproduce the problem (without any additional fix)

```python
#### Reproducible code only ----
from sktime.datasets import load_uschange
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import SlidingWindowSplitter

y, X = load_uschange()

forecaster = ARIMA(
    order=(1, 1, 0),
    seasonal_order=(0, 1, 0, 2),
    suppress_warnings=True
)

FH = [2, 3]
cv = SlidingWindowSplitter(fh=FH)

for i, split in enumerate(cv.split(y)):
    if i == 0:
        test_split = split[1]
        train_split = split[0]

        #### This does not work ----
        print("\nWith current sktime functionality")       
        try:
            forecaster.fit(y.iloc[train_split], X=X.iloc[train_split], fh=FH)
            
            X_test = X.iloc[test_split]
            print(f"X_test:\n {X_test}")
            y_pred = forecaster.predict(X=X_test)
            print(f"\nPredictions (current sktime):\n{y_pred}")
        except ValueError as error:
            print("sktime errored out")
            print(error)
```
@fkiraly Is anyone working on this splitter fix? Thanks!

I think this is somewhat related to https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3075 and the underlying issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3071. The splitter's test window is defined by the values in the forecasting horizon, without implicit modifications. Assuming that a user wants test window `[1, 2, 3]` although only forecasting horizons `[2, 3]` are given seems to be a very strong assumption. Just thinking out loud: would it be better to solve this problem in some other place without guessing work for the user?

Or, may I ask you, what is the motivation to omit horizon 1 in the first place? Is it a real use case?

> Assuming that a user wants test window [1, 2, 3] ...

@khrapovs I don't think there are any assumptions here. In my example, the user is explicitly wanting to test future points 2 and 3 only (FH = [2, 3]). This is quite a common use case as outlined in

- https://robjhyndman.com/hyndsight/tscv/
- https://github.com/pycaret/pycaret/discussions/1942

The user does not care about the first future point (it is just needed internally by sktime to work correctly, else we get the error).

```python
X array dims (n_rows) != n_periods
```

Also, it seems that this use case (forecast horizon with gaps) works well for univariate data (without exogenous variables) but fails only when exogenous variables are added. So it was supposed to be supported by design if I understand this correctly.

@khrapovs ok, I see this now. It looks like sktime also faced the same issue and fixed it here using a similar approach.

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4164639e1c521b112711c045d0f7e63013c1e4eb/sktime/forecasting/model_evaluation/_functions.py#L196

@khrapovs I was still wondering is this functionality should be moved into the CV object `split` method. So instead of just providing the `train` and `test` split, maybe it can provide `train`, `y_test` and `X_test` splits?

I am sure others will face the same issue and will have to replicate the implementation in some way again. Having this inside CV would be convenient.

@khrapovs I believe sktime is having to do the same inside `temporal_train_test_split` as well (although using a different code). Here too X_test is returned without and index gaps and y_test is returned with index gaps (if fh has gaps). So there is replication of functionality in 2 places now.

### In `temporal_train_test_split`
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/bd52e9b1ded581891c98b165871305ea11077cbf/sktime/forecasting/model_selection/_split.py#L1409

### In `evaluate`:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4164639e1c521b112711c045d0f7e63013c1e4eb/sktime/forecasting/model_evaluation/_functions.py#L196

Hence, I feel it would be good to update `splits` to returns both `X_test` and `y_test` indices (in addition to the `train` indices. 

cc: @fkiraly @aiwalter

@ngupta23 Just to understand your proposal very clearly. You want `sktime.forecasting.model_selection._split.BaseSplitter.split` to return a tuple of 4 arrays, instead of 2? `y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test`? And it is expected that `y_test` has the same gaps as `fh`, while `X_test` has no gaps?
